aws::graph::propositions: # Juneau Alaska Aviation Accident Report
The accident occurred in Juneau, Alaska.
The accident occurred on June 11, 2013, at 21:00 Local time.
The aircraft involved was a Piper PA-18A 150.
The defining event was loss of control on ground.
The flight was conducted under Part 91: General aviation - Personal.
The accident number was ANC13CA055.
The aircraft registration was N1886P.
The aircraft sustained substantial damage.
There were 2 occupants in the aircraft.
No injuries occurred in the accident.
The pilot was flying the airplane from the front seat.
The airplane owner was in the rear seat.
The airplane owner is also a pilot.
The pilot in the front seat turned final early to maintain aircraft separation.
The pilot in the front seat made a short and slightly steep final approach.
The pilot in the front seat flared the airplane a little high during landing.
The airplane bounced twice during the landing.
During the second bounce, the pilot in the rear seat applied corrective input.
The pilot in the front seat could not recall if she continued to apply control inputs.
The pilot in the front seat could not recall if the pilot in the rear seat had assumed the controls.
Positive control transfer was not accomplished between the pilots.
The airplane ground looped to the right.
The left wing tip struck the runway.
The left wing was substantially damaged when the wing tip struck the runway.
The pilot reported no preaccident mechanical malfunctions with the airplane.
The pilot reported no preaccident mechanical failures with the airplane.
The National Transportation Safety Board determined the probable cause of the accident.
The probable cause was the pilot not maintaining directional control while attempting to recover from a bounced landing.
The finding was that directional control was not attained/maintained.

text:
# Aviation Investigation Final Report

## Location:
Juneau, Alaska

## Date & Time: 
June 11, 2013, 21:00 Local

## Aircraft:
Piper PA-18A 150

## Defining Event:
Loss of control on ground

## Flight Conducted Under:
Part 91: General aviation - Personal

## Accident Number:
ANC13CA055

## Registration:
N1886P

## Aircraft Damage:
Substantial

## Injuries:
2 None

## Analysis

The pilot stated that she was flying the airplane from the front seat, and the airplane owner (who is also a pilot) was in the rear seat. The pilot in the front seat turned final early to maintain aircraft separation and made a short and slightly steep final approach. She said that while landing she flared the airplane a little high, and it bounced twice during the landing. During the second bounce, the pilot in the rear seat assisted the recovery by applying corrective input. The pilot in the front seat could not recall if she continued to apply control inputs or if the pilot in the rear seat had assumed the controls. Positive control transfer was not accomplished. The airplane ground looped to the right, substantially damaging the left wing when the wing tip struck the runway. The pilot reported no preaccident mechanical malfunctions or failures with the airplane that would have precluded normal operation.

## Probable Cause and Findings

The National Transportation Safety Board determines the probable cause(s) of this accident to be:
The pilot did not maintain directional control while attempting to recover from a bounced landing.

## Findings

| Aircraft | Directional control - Not attained/maintained |
| --- | --- |

---
